Graphical abstract Though carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are widely applied in industry, their large-scale use in catalysis is still limited. This work studies cobalt-based CNT-supported catalysts with 20 and 30 % metal loadings in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis at relevant conditions. The evolution of catalyst and support structures was analyzed by a combination of physicochemical methods at different stages of catalysts preparation, long-term tests, regeneration, and re-test. Wax accumulation was suggested to be the main reason for catalyst deactivation, while sintering and carbidization did not strongly affected the catalyst performance. Moreover, sintering played a positive role by increasing conversion and C5+ selectivity because of the consolidation of low active small particles. The reductive regeneration of the used catalysts restored their maximum activities. The mild and optimally chosen conditions of the catalyst preparation, activation and regeneration preserved the support structure improving the overall stability of the Co/CNT catalysts that is necessary for large-scale catalytic applications. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis CO hydrogenation Cobalt catalyst Carbon nanotubes Catalyst stability Regeneration Structure evolution Particle sintering 1 Introduction The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is an industrial process realized on small and large scales in different countries over the world [1]. FTS implies catalytic hydrogenation of CO into hydrocarbons, and it is a part of the X-to-liquid (XTL) technologies for converting natural gas, coal, and biomass into valuable products such as fuel, lubricants, oils, etc. This process is generally realized over Fe- or Co-based catalysts due to their relatively low price, high activity and selectivity, while cobalt catalysts are more stable and produce mainly linear n-alkanes [2,3]. Supports are usually used, especially in the case of Co-based systems, to disperse metal phase and decrease local overheating. Only oxide supports, such as silica, alumina, and titania are used in industry because they are relatively cheap, porous, and widely available [4]. At the same time, these supports possess several drawbacks, like low thermal conductivity and formation of inactive complex oxides with the active metal [5,6]. Low thermal conductivity facilitates temperature fluctuations inside the reactor, while unreducible complex oxides decrease the amount of the active phase. Therefore, the expensive noble metal promotion is usually required to increase the reducibility of the active metal [7,8]. A lot of works devoted to the application of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as an FTS catalyst support have been published over the last 15 years [9–16]. This interest was stimulated by the unique set of CNT properties, such as inertness, mechanical and thermal stability, tunable textural properties, possibility of surface functionalization and doping. The catalysts supported on CNTs showed many times higher activities than those on oxide supports [5,15,17–19]. It is important that the price of CNTs is constantly coming down while their annual production is increasing [20]. Actually, CNTs is the first and the only structured carbon nanomaterial produced in a large industrial scale. Though CNTs have been successfully applied in composites and electrochemical devices, they are still not used in the catalytic industry, including FTS, mainly because of rather high price, poor homogeneity, possible toxicity, low bulk density, powder nature, and low stability in aggressive medium (air, hydrogen) at elevated temperatures [21–23]. The oxidative functionalization of CNTs is a powerful technique to modify their properties for catalytic applications [24–27]. This functionalization immobilizes on the CNT surface mostly carboxyl and hydroxyl species and introduces defects. Oxygen-containing groups anchor metal ions during impregnation due to the electrostatic interaction, while defects prevent particle migration at high temperatures. Moreover, this modification noticeably increases the bulk density of CNTs, decreases the powderiness, and allows tuning the catalyst particle size. Nevertheless, the stability of CNTs in air and hydrogen is low at elevated temperatures and, therefore, the conditions of metal salt decomposition, reduction and regeneration should be carefully chosen for CNT-supported catalysts. In the majority of works Co/CNTs and Fe/CNTs FTS catalysts are tested for rather short-times (up to 100–150 h) only to compare their activities with oxide-supported catalysts or to study the effect of support functionalization with oxygen or nitrogen groups on the catalyst performance [5,9,11,13,28–30]. Only a limited number of long-term studies of the stability of Co/CNT catalysts are available in the literature [14,31–34]. Sintering, carbon deposition and oxidation of cobalt particles were suggested to be the main reasons for the catalyst deactivation. At the same time, the majority of these works did not analyze the structure evolution of the catalyst during FTS: only fresh and used catalysts were studied. The same is true for the stability of supports and their transformations during FTS. Present study aims to reveal the structure changes and stability of Co catalyst supported on oxidized CNTs under relevant FTS conditions and after regeneration. The treatment conditions at each stage of the catalyst lifecycle (annealing, reduction, and regeneration) were carefully chosen to preserve the support structure. The TEM, XRD, XPS, and Raman techniques were used to trace the changes in the support and catalyst structure, while the thermal analysis (TGA-MS) allowed us to study the wax deposition. The oxidative and reductive techniques were applied for catalyst regeneration. Present work expands the results published earlier for 20 wt.% Co-catalyst [34] by providing deeper insight into the deactivation reasons, sintering mechanism, wax deposition, and regeneration. 2 Experimental 2.1 CNT synthesis and oxidation Multiwall CNTs were synthesized at 750 °C by catalytic pyrolysis of hexane over the Co-Mo/MgO catalyst [35]. To burn the amorphous fraction in CNTs, the synthesized material was annealing at 400оC in air flow. After that, metal impurities were removed by washing CNTs with concentrated HCl (Chimmed, Russia). Purified CNTs were designated as “CNTp”. They were oxidized via refluxing in concentrated HNO3 (Chimmed, Russia, ∼70 %, density – 1.4 g/cm3, purity – 99.999 %) for 7 h, filtered, washed with distilled water to neutral pH and dried at 110 °C. Oxidized CNTs were named as “CNTox”. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Co catalysts were prepared by the impregnation of CNTox with Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (Vecton, Russia, 99 % purity) ethanol solution for metal loading of 20 and 30 wt.%. After solvent evaporation at 70 °C the samples were dried at 110 °C for 16 h. The catalysts were named as xCoC where x – is the weight Co loading. The impregnated samples were heated initially to 100 °C (10 K/min) and then to 250 °C (1 K/min) in N2 flow and annealed at this temperature for 4 h. Such a low temperature was chosen to avoid the CNT oxidation by NO2 and O2 releasing under nitrate decomposition. 2.3 Catalytic tests The annealed catalyst (1 g) was mixed with quartz powder and reduced in situ in a stainless steel vertical reactor (i.d. of 10 mm) in H2/N2 flow (1:1 vol ratio) at 350 °C (heating rate of 10 K/min up to 100 °C and then 1 K/min up to 350 °C) for 8 h. After reduction the reactor was cooled down to 170 °C and the gas flow was switched to the CO:H2:N2 mixture at a ratio of 2:4:1 at 20 bar (4.2 nL·gcat –1 h–1) in which N2 was an internal standard. After that the catalyst was heated up to the reaction temperature of 220 °C at a rate of 1 K/min. The standard test time was about 3 weeks (500 h). Shorter tests for 50, 100, 330, or 350 h were performed to trace the structural changes in the catalysts. Gas and liquid products were analyzed on a Kristallux 4000 M gas chromatograph (“Meta-chrom”, Russia) using a SKT-4 capillary column and a flame-ionization detector for hydrocarbons, and a ZB-1 packed column and a thermal conductivity detector for CO, CO2, N2, and CH4. For physicochemical characterization, the catalyst samples after reduction and after FTS were passivated overnight in 1% air/N2 flow. The following equations were used for the calculation of CO conversion (XCO), selectivities (S) to different products, activity (A), and TOF: XCO = (1 – NCOout/NCOin)*100 %; S(CO2) = NCO2/(NCOin – NCOout)*100 %; S(CH4) = NCH4/(NCOin – NCOout)*100 %; S(C2-C4) = N(C2-C4)/(NCOin – NCOout)*100 %; S(C5+) = 100 % - S(CO2) - S(CH4) - S(C2-C4); A (cobalt time yield) = X*RCOin/mCo, where RCOin is molar CO flow in mol/s; TOF = X*RCOin/NCo /D, where D is dispersion, RCOin is molar CO flow in mol/s. The cobalt metal dispersion (D) in the catalysts was calculated from the Sauter mean diameter d32 [36,37] assuming spherical uniform particles with the surface density of Co atoms of 14.6 nm–2 [38]. According to these assumptions D(%) = 96/d32(nm). 2.4 Catalyst regeneration Two catalyst regeneration techniques were used in this work. In the oxidative technique solid hydrocarbons were extracted by boiling the used catalyst in hexane with further filtration and drying at 40 °C. The dried sample was annealed in air at a temperature of 300 °C chosen based on the TG-MS data and then treated in a 40 mL/min hydrogen flow for 4 h at 350 °C. In the reductive technique the used catalyst was exposed to air at room temperature and then treated in a 40 mL/min hydrogen flow for 4 h at 350 °C. The 30 wt. % catalyst after reductive regeneration was re-tested in FTS for 100 h at the same conditions described in the Section 2.3. 2.5 Support evolution study To study the evolution of the support structure cobalt was washed out from the annealed, reduced, tested, and regenerated catalysts by ultrasonication in concentrated HCl followed by washing with distilled water until neutral pH. To remove wax the used samples were also pre-washed in toluene under ultrasonic treatment for 1 h. The designations of the catalyst and support samples are denoted in Fig. 1 . 2.6 Characterization The specific surface area (SBET) was measured by low-temperature nitrogen physisorption using an AUTOSORB-1C/MS/TPR gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome, USA). Prior to analysis, samples were degassed at 250 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The surface state of the supports was analyzed by XPS using an Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer (Kratos Analytical Ltd., UK). The pass energies of the analyzer were 160 eV for survey spectra and 40 eV for high-resolution scans. Raman spectra were registered on a LabRam HR800 UV microscope-spectrometer using 5 mW argon laser excitation. X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2θ range from 20 to 70°on a Stoe Stadi P instrument equipped with the Ni-filtered CuKα X-ray tube. The WINXPOW software was used for phase identification. Diffraction peaks were fitted with a Pseudo-Voigt profile using the OriginLab software. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) with hydrogen was carried out on a USGA-101 chemisorption analyzer (Unisit, Russia). The analyzed sample was placed in a quartz reactor and heated in a mixture of 5% H2 + Ar (30 mL/min) from 30 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Changes in the composition of the gas mixture during analysis were registered by a thermal conductivity detector operated at 60 °C. The annealed catalysts were analyzed by XRD and TPR. The morphology and structure of the catalysts were studied by HRTEM on a JEM 2100 F/Cs JEOL microscope. For this study, the catalysts were reduced as described in Section 2.3 and passivated overnight in 1% air/N2 flow. The temperature ranges of the decomposition of wax on the catalyst surface were determined in an air flow by thermal gravimetry analysis combined with mass-spectrometry of evolved gases (TGA–MS) using a Netzsch STA 449 Jupiter instrument coupled with a Netzsch QMS Aeolos 403 mass spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and fresh catalysts The purified CNT support (CNTp) contained multi-walled cylindrical nanotubes of 5–30 nm in diameter with occasional defects on their surface (Fig. 2 a,b). The support after oxidation (CNTox) compacted and both the external and internal surfaces of nanotubes corrugated (Fig. 2c,d), which agrees with the literature data [35,39,40]. SBET of CNTox was 210 m2/g. Co3O4 was the only Co-containing phase detected by XRD in both annealed catalysts (Fig. 3 a), which is typical for FTS supported systems. The TPR profiles of the annealed catalysts (Fig. 3b) can be roughly divided into three temperature ranges [35,41,42]. Co3O4 particles weakly interacting with the support are reduced at low temperatures of 200–300 °C (range I). The residual cobalt salt can also contribute to this region despite the fact the annealing temperature (250 °C) was higher than the decomposition temperature of supported cobalt nitrate (210–220 °C [43,44]). Smaller Co3O4 particles in 20CoC-N2 stronger interacted with the support than those in 30CoC-N2, which resulted in the less pronounced hydrogen consumption peak in this temperature range for the former catalyst. Range II (300–450 °C) corresponds to the reduction of most cobalt oxide particles to metallic state, while the smallest CoO nanoparticles are completely reduced only in range III. In addition, methanation of CNT defects contributes to TPR profiles in this temperature range. The decomposition of residual oxygen functional groups with CO or CO2 release and further reduction of carbon oxides by hydrogen to methane over Co particles are also possible in temperature range III. The particle size in 30CoC-N2 was slightly higher than that in 20CoC-N2 (Fig. 3c,d). Therefore, the former sample contained more smaller crystallites of 5–10 nm in size. Cobalt particles were observed both inside and outside CNTs. 3.2 Evolution of catalysts during FTS After in situ reduction in H2/N2 flow at ambient pressure, both catalysts were tested for ∼3 weeks (500 h) at relevant FTS conditions. The dependencies of CO conversion and selectivity to different products on time on stream (TOS) are presented in Fig. 4 . The observed induction period, at which CO conversion slightly increased, was shorter for 20 wt.% catalyst (∼ 50 h) than for 30 % one (∼100 h). The increase in C5+ selectivity and the decrease in CH4 one during induction period can be attributed both to the reduction of residual oxide particles by syngas and to sintering of particles smaller than 6–8 nm. Such small nanoparticles can promote methane production and show poor activity because of the high hydrogen concentration on their surface and formation of strongly bonded complexes between CO and active sites [45–47]. Therefore, their disappearance during sintering may explain the observed TOS dependencies of C5+ and CH4 selectivities during induction period, which was earlier proposed for Co/CNT catalysts [32,34]. 20CoC was stable during 500 h of FTS while 30CoC showed a noticeable deactivation after 300 h on stream. At the same time, the regeneration in H2 flow of the latter catalyst tested for 500 h restored its highest conversion. This deactivation was not accompanied by the selectivity changes. To understand the reasons for these effects we studied the catalyst structure before, during and after FTS tests. TEM analysis revealed the sintering of metal nanoparticles in 20CoC during FTS (Fig. 5 ). Particles less than 10 nm in size dominated in the reduced catalyst locating both inside and outside CNTs (Fig. 5a–c). The ratio of inside and outside particles was about 50:50 according to the TEM image analysis. During the induction period particles larger than 5 nm were formed, while the portion of smaller particles decreased (Fig. 5d–f). A noticeable sintering was observed for particles outside CNTs, while the size of particles inside nanotubes remained unchanged (Fig. 5e) but their portion decreased. Cobalt crystallites smaller than 6 nm show low activity and facilitate both the formation of strongly bonded CHx intermediates and high hydrogen concentration on the metallic surface [45–48]. Therefore, the increase in the particle size in the first two days of FTS was the reason for the growth of both CO conversion and selectivity to C5+ fraction (Fig. 4a). Smaller particles migrate easier because their Tammann and Hüttig temperatures of bulk and surface atom mobility are much lower than those for larger particles [49]. The catalyst performance was rather stable between 50–60 and 330–370 h on stream and only a slight decrease in activity was observed during the third week. The particle size did not also change after the end of the induction period to the end of the second week but noticeably increased during the last 150 h of the test (Fig. 5d–l). Interestingly, this increase in the particle size did not significantly reduce the CO conversion, which can be explained by the changes in the cobalt particles size distribution (Fig. 5l). Probably the percentage of less active 2.5–5.0 nm particles significantly decreased compensating the total decrease in the metal surface area. There are two possible mechanisms of cobalt sintering during FTS: coalescence and Ostwald ripening. Though coalescence is usually considered as the main mechanism [50,51], the atomic migration is also possible via carbonyl-assisted mechanism [49,52] and, in general, cannot be excluded [31]. Nevertheless, based on the changes in the particle size distribution we can propose coalescence to be a dominating sintering mechanism in 20CoC. In the case of Ostwald ripening the formation of both huge crystallites and small nanoparticles should occur. In contrast, we observed the disappearance of smaller particles and the increasing number of larger ones. The TEM images of the used 20CoC catalyst show the formation of agglomerates of small particles (Fig. 5e), which also point to coalescence. Noticeable wax formation was observed during the second and third weeks of the test (Fig. 5h,k). The absence of particles inside CNTs in the 20CoC-500 sample points to their disappearance under the FTS conditions. They probably migrated from channels and sintered with particles outside CNTs via H2O-induced coalescence route or atomic migration through the carbonyl-assisted way. In contrast to our results the high sintering stability of particles inside CNTs due to the confinement effect and their preservation in the used catalyst was demonstrated in [32]. The possible explanation of this difference may lie in the different ratio of particles inside and outside CNTs in the fresh catalysts: ∼50:50 in our case and in ∼70:30 in [32]. Metal sintering was also observed by TEM in used 30CoC, but with a different dependence on time on stream. The most intensive sintering was detected during the first two weeks of FTS. Initially, the same as for 20CoC, ultra-small (less than 5 nm) nanoparticles disappeared (Fig. 6 a-g), which increased both the CO conversion and C5+ selectivity (Fig. 4b). Interestingly, the high particle shape anisotropy was observed in the reduced catalyst (30CoC-H2) (Fig. 6a-c) but mostly spherical crystallites appeared in the used ones (Fig. 6e,h,k). The elongated particle shape in the fresh catalyst originated from the high metal concentration and interaction between cobalt species and functional groups on the support surface. Metal salt covers the support surface forming high aspect ratio particles, while the harsh conditions of FTS transformed these particles into the most stable spherical crystallites. The surface restructuring during the induction period of FTS via the carbonyl-assisted mechanism was previously proposed in [53]. This restructuring may change the surface texture and CoCo coordination number [46,54]. Smaller portion of particles inside CNTs (∼20–30 %) was observed in 30CoC-H2 compared to 20CoC-H2, apparently, due to the diffusion limitations during the impregnation stage. A slightly lower mean particle size in 30CoC-H2 than that in 30CoC-N2 can be attributed to the high density of particles in the samples and anisotropy of their shapes that complicates particle size calculation. The overlap between the standard deviations (σ) of the mean crystallite diameters in 30CoC-N2 and 30CoC-H2 (σ = 2.3 nm and 1.7 nm, respectively) testifies to the similar particle sizes in these samples. Stronger sintering in 30CoC than in 20CoC led to the formation of great number of particles larger than 20 nm in the former catalyst and domination of the coalescence mechanism until 350 h on stream. The water-assisted mechanism of sintering implies the formation of oxygen-containing complexes on the particle surface and the increase in their mobility, thus, higher water concentration should lead to a more intensive sintering. The CO conversion over 30CoC was higher and hence the water concentration in the reaction mixture was also higher, which enhanced sintering. Moreover, higher metal concentration at the close initial particle size led to a lower distance between crystals, which also enhanced sintering. Interestingly, larger portion of particles smaller than 10 nm was detected in 30CoC-500 (Fig. 6m) than in 30CoC-330, which can be an evidence for Ostwald ripening. The change in the sintering mechanism may be caused by the strong accumulation of heavy products in the catalyst and diffusion limitations for cobalt particles. At the same time, migration of cobalt atoms seems to be independent on the wax precipitation. Similar to 20CoC-500, practically no particles were detected inside CNTs in 30CoC-500. Interestingly, the most intensive deactivation of 30 % Co/CNTs was observed during the third week of the test, when the particle sintering was not as intense as at the beginning of the test. Most likely, this trend resulted from the gradual accumulation of viscous wax and, probably, amorphous carbon that blocked the active sites. Though the sintering of metal particles and carbidization were widely believed to be the main mechanisms of the FTS catalyst deactivation, some recent results have shown that wax accumulation and pore blocking are the most crucial factors [55]. Wax accumulation was also observed in the present study. We used TGA-MS to compare the amount of wax in the catalysts by monitoring the signal of m/z = 18 under heating in air flow (Fig. 7 ). The peak at ∼300–400 °C in the TGA-MS curves of the used catalysts corresponds to wax burning and its intensity increases with increasing TOS. Regeneration of the catalyst in a hydrogen flow removed the wax and restored the catalyst activity up to its maximum value (Fig. 4b). Table 1 summarizes the catalyst activities and TOFs at different stages of FTS. The highest activities, TOFs and selectivities are rather similar for both catalysts (Fig. 4, Table 1). This is unusual because the increase in metal loading typically reduces the catalyst activity due to the particle size growth. It seems that highly oxidized CNTs have high capacity towards the active phase, therefore, even at high metal loading all cobalt can be effectively dispersed over the support surface. At the same time, this implies the smaller gaps between particles on the highly loaded support surface that is one of the reasons for faster particle sintering in the 30 % Co/CNTs catalyst. The selected samples were studied by XRD. For this purpose, the used catalysts were separated from quartz and treated with toluene to remove wax. Nevertheless, the XRD patterns of the used samples were rather noisy probably due to both residual quartz and unwashed wax (Fig. 8 ). In 20CoC predominantly metallic cobalt was found after the induction period (Fig. 8a), while a noticeable amount of Co2C was detected after three weeks of the test (Fig. 8b). Interestingly, no hcp-Co was observed in 20CoC-500 in contrast to 20CoC-50, which may indicate the predominant transformation of this phase into carbide due to the higher activity and defectiveness of the surface of hexagonal Co clusters. Nevertheless, the XRD profiles are rather noisy to completely exclude the presence of the hcp-Co peaks. The carbide phase is generally believed to reduce the catalyst activity in FTS due to the lowering of the density of active cobalt sites on the catalyst surface [56,57]. Earlier, Tavasoli et al. attributed the decrease in CO conversion over the 20Co/CNT system mainly to the bulk carbide formation [32]. Tsakoumis et al. in their review on the nature of deactivation of Co-based FTS catalysts [50] concluded that the bulk carbidization was one of the possible reasons for the activity loss, but this process was reversible and hydrogen treatment at mild conditions could convert Co2C into the highly active hcp-phase. In the present study we did not observed a noticeable deactivation of 20 % Co/CNTs despite the carbide formation, which contradicts the literature data. Probably, the critical amount of carbide should be accumulated in the system before the catalyst performance started reducing. The authors of work [58] concluded that though cobalt carbide is a stable phase at FTS conditions, its amount cannot be higher than 5–10 % of the available Co. Therefore, it cannot make a noticeable contribution to the overall deactivation. Moreover, several recent studies revealed a positive effect of Co carbides in FTS. For example, it was proposed that Co2C provides additional active site for the reaction and effectively adsorbs CO [59]. High selectivities to light olefins [60] and high alcohols [61] were observed over Co2C. Among the catalyst with high cobalt loading, only the sample after the induction period (Fig. 8c) was available for XRD study because 30CoC-330 and 30CoC-500 were completely used for regeneration study and re-test, respectively. Anyway, the XRD pattern of 30CoC-100 showed the phase composition similar to 20CoC-50: both fcc-Co, hcp-Co and two CoO phases were detected in addition to the graphite phase of CNTs and different types of silica from the diluent. This phase composition reflects the “core-shell” structure of particles in the used catalysts with the metal core and oxide shell (Fig. 6i,l). We can conclude that the main reason for deactivation was probably the accumulation of wax over the catalyst surface. This agrees with the recent results for oxide-supported catalysts, for which the decrease in CO conversion directly depended on the GHSV [55] and selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons [62]. Accumulation of viscous wax blocked pores and active sites hindering the diffusion of reagents and products. No noticeable oxidation of cobalt was observed, which agrees with the low probability of oxidation in the presence of hydrogen [31]. Sintering of metal particles during the induction period played a positive role in the catalytic performance. The smallest crystallites are partially inactive in FTS due to the formation of stable Co-CHx complexes and higher hydrogen concentration on their surface compared to larger particles [45–48]. Thus, we can propose that the disappearance of these particles during the induction period led to the growth of both CO conversion and selectivity to C5+ fraction. Further sintering did not affect the catalyst performance because particles of 5–15 nm in size dominated in the catalysts even after 3 weeks of the tests according to the TEM data (Fig. 5l and Fig. 6m). This particle sizes are close to the optimal FTS particle size range of 5–10 nm established in [46,63,64]. 3.3 Regeneration In our work we used the two most popular approaches to catalyst regeneration: the oxidative and reductive ones [14,65]. In the first approach the catalyst was annealed in air at 300 °C and further reduced at 350 °C, while in the second one it was reduced after air exposure at room temperature. In our case the hydrogen treatment was enough to restore the activity to its maximum value (Table 1, Fig. 4b), which agrees with the previously published data [14]. This treatment slightly reduced the particle size and effectively removed wax from the used 30CoC catalyst. The removal of wax was confirmed by a dramatic drop of the TG-MS water release signal after regeneration (Fig. 7). The XRD patterns of the regenerated and re-tested catalysts evidence to the decomposition of carbides under hydrogen treatment (Fig. 8d,e). Interestingly, the oxidative regeneration generated small (< 6 nm) particles and their agglomerates (Fig. 9 d–f). Earlier this phenomenon was attributed to the formation of oxide clusters on the surface and in the bulk of metal particles and their further reduction into smaller separated particles [66–68]. No decrease in the particle size was observed after the reductive regeneration of used 20CoC (Fig. 9a–c) in contrast to the catalyst with high metal loading, in which this effect was well pronounced (Fig. 9g–i). It was earlier predicted that cobalt particles became smaller during oxidation – reduction cycle only if their size was higher than the critical size of about 10–15 nm [66]. The mean Co particle sizes in the used 20CoC-350 and 30CoC-330 catalysts were 6.4 and 12.6 nm, respectively. Therefore, we can suggest that the critical size was achieved only in 30CoC-330. Along with the 30CoC catalyst tested for 350, the reductive regeneration was also used for 30CoC-500. After regeneration, the CO conversion of this catalyst and, hence, the activity restored to their maximum values. Moreover, the particle size in the regenerated and re-tested for 100 h 30CoC-R-FTS was significantly lower than that in 30CoC-500 reflecting higher degree of the crystallite redispersion in the catalyst with initially larger crystals (Fig. 9j–l, Table 1). No carbide phase was detected in 30CoC-R-FTS by XRD (Fig. 8e). It seems that the critical carbon concentration on the catalyst surface or critical TOS should be achieved to initiate the formation of the cobalt carbide phases. Our results suggest the following optimal strategy for the regeneration of Co/CNT catalysts. Because the wax accumulation plays a noticeable role in catalyst deactivation, a simple periodic reactor purge can be used when conversion start decreasing. If this is not enough to restore the activity to its maximum value, the pressure should be decreased to 1 bar and the catalyst after a short air exposure at room temperature should be reduced at a temperature not higher than 350 °C. This stage is necessary to re-disperse particles over the support surface. Because of the metallic state of the cobalt particle core, only a short reduction is required. In the case of strong sintering, the temperature of air exposure can be increased but not higher than 300 °C. These soft conditions are necessary to avoid the destruction of support structure during regeneration of Co/CNT catalysts (see the following section). If the degree of sintering in the used catalyst is low, a high-temperature air exposure may result in the formation of particles less than 5 nm in size, which decreases the catalyst activity. 3.4 Evolution of CNT support during FTS Several factors limit the large-scale application of CNTs in the catalytic industry. The relatively high cost of CNTs, that was crucial 10 years ago, has been decreasing during the last decade due to the optimization of the synthesis technique and growth of the CNT production. Another problem is a large variation in the parameters of CNTs from different suppliers. The difference in the number of layers, aspect ratio, purity and defectiveness of CNTs can affect the performance of CNT supported catalysts [69–71]. The mechanical properties of bulk carbon nanomaterials, in particular CNTs, are not always favorable to catalytic applications because of their powder nature, controversial data on the attrition resistance and poor stability at temperatures higher than 350–400 °C in such aggressive media as air and hydrogen. Though the powder nature of a CNT-based material can be overcome by the preparation of monoliths, gels, fibers and coatings [23,69,72], the possible structure evolution of CNTs during FTS still prevents their practical application in catalysis. This issue stimulated us to investigate the changes in the structure and defectiveness of the CNT support at different stages of its catalytic lifecycle. For this purpose, we washed out hydrocarbons and cobalt from 30 % Co/CNTs samples after different stages of catalyst preparation and tests and studied the washed supports by Raman spectroscopy and XPS. XPS showed the decrease in the oxygen concentration in CNTs after each stage of catalyst lifecycle (Fig. 10 a). The highest oxygen loss was observed after catalyst annealing, which agrees with the previous works [34,35]. Oxidized CNTs (CNTox) contained predominantly carboxylic groups (Fig. 10b,c) that are the most labile and decompose at the lowest temperature [73–75], thus, the oxygen loss at the annealing stage corresponds mainly to the removal of these functionalities. Interestingly, CO concentration increased after annealing that can result from the transformation of carboxyls to lactones, hydroxyls or ethers. Further catalyst treatments (reduction, FTS test, regeneration and re-test) gradually decreased the content of both carboxylic and CO species and only ∼20 % of the initial oxygen remained on the support surface after the re-test. Though the role of oxygen functional groups in the particle stabilization on a carbon support during FTS is not clear, we believe that they mainly enhance the dispersion of the cobalt salt on the support surface during impregnation [35], while defects on the support surface are responsible for the stability of metal particles towards sintering during activation and FTS test [76]. Nevertheless, oxygen-containing groups can also slightly contribute to the overall stability of particles. The soft annealing and activation conditions (250 and 350 °C, respectively) used in this work reduced the content of oxygen containing groups in the CNT support only by about 50 % compared to the 70–75 % drop observed earlier in the CNT support after annealing and reduction at 400 °C [35]. Raman spectroscopy is a bulk technique that allows tracing the changes in the defectiveness of a carbon material. Usually Raman spectra of multi-walled CNTs contain several characteristic bands. The main bands are the G band at ∼1580–1600 cm−1 corresponding to the E2g vibrational mode of the ideal graphitic lattice, the D1 band at ∼1350 cm−1 assigned to the symmetry breaking of the graphitic lattice by edge atoms and heteroatoms, and the G' (2D) band corresponding to the two-phonon process and usually associated with layer interactions in the graphitic material [77–79]. In the 900–1900 cm−1 region additional bands can be also observed in defective graphene-like nanocarbons: the D2 component at ∼1600–1620 cm−1 is usually assigned to sidewall defects and small graphene clusters, while the D3 and D4 bands at ∼1500 and ∼1150–1250 cm−1, respectively, refer to the amorphous (sp3-C or mixed sp2+sp3-C carbon) impurities in the graphitic material [76,80–83]. The intensity ratios of D bands to the G band provide information on the corresponding types of defectiveness. In the present study we analyzed the 900–1900 cm−1 region of the Raman spectra of the CNT support of the 30 wt.% cobalt catalyst at different stages of its lifecycle. For this purpose, hydrocarbons and cobalt were washed out from the catalyst by the treatment in toluene (only for used catalysts) and HCl. Fig. 11 demonstrates the changes in the 900–1900 cm−1 region of the Raman spectra of the CNT support and the calculated band parameters. The ID1/IG, ID3/IG, and ID4/IG ratios did not change after annealing and reduction of the catalyst (Fig. 11a,b,g). In the previous study we investigated the Raman spectra of the annealed and reduced 15 wt.% Co/CNT catalyst and found that the reduction led to a noticeable increase in the ID1/IG ratio, which was attributed to the hydrogen etching of graphene surface near metal nanoparticles with the methane production [76]. The absence of changes in the present work confirms that 350 °C is a more suitable temperature for this step: it allows reducing cobalt oxide without support etching. At the same time, the ID2/IG ratio slightly decreased after nitrate decomposition and catalyst activation reflecting the removal of oxygen groups and fragments from the top layer as it was observed in [76]. The contribution of the D3 and D4 bands attributed to amorphous sp3- or sp3-/sp2-carbon is much more noticeable in the Raman spectra of the support after FTS (Fig. 11c,f,g), which correlates well with wax deposition on the support surface during catalytic process. Interestingly, the XPS analysis did not show any increase in sp3-C–C component in the C1s spectrum of the CNT support after FTS (Fig. 10b). The toluene treatment probably removes wax only from the surface of CNT aggregates. As a result, the surface sensitive XPS technique could not detect wax in the bulk of aggregates in contrast to the bulk sensitive Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectra of 30C-R-O2 and 30C-R-H2 (Fig. 11d,e) demonstrate that wax was completely removed from the catalyst by both oxidative and reductive regeneration treatments, which agrees with the TGA-MS data (Fig. 7). Moreover, the parameters of Raman spectra of the support after oxidative regeneration are close to those of 30C-H2 (support of the fresh reduced catalyst), which testifies to the non-destructive nature of the oxidative treatment. At the same time, the ID1/IG ratio noticeably increased after reductive regeneration (Fig. 11g). It was surprising as this regeneration technique differed from the oxidative one only by the absence of high-temperature air exposure of the catalyst. The only possible explanation for the difference in the ID1/IG ratio for the supports after reductive and oxidative regenerations relies on the presence of wax during hydrogenation in the former case. Hydrogenation of the catalyst in the presence of wax probably initiated the formation and further etching of graphitic-like soot on the support surface. Nevertheless, the activity of the catalysts completely restored after reductive regeneration. The preliminary reactor purge with nitrogen at 250–350 °C should prevent the increase in the support defectiveness under reductive regeneration. The widths of the D1 and G bands are usually considered as parameters of structure homogeneity of a carbon material. The FWHMs of the G band are rather similar for the catalysts without wax, which suggests that the activation and regeneration conditions were appropriately chosen (Fig. 11h). The FWHM of the D1 band slightly decreased after annealing and reduction of the fresh catalyst because of the removal of functional groups and structuring of graphene layer edges, but it significantly grew after FTS due to the product deposition. The relative area of the G band in the 900–1900 cm−1 region characterizes the relative amount of carbon with the perfect graphitic structure. The evolution of this area also confirms the above-mentioned conclusions about the non-destructive nature of the activation and oxidative regeneration (Fig. 11i). In addition, it illustrates the deposition of non-graphitic substances on the CNT surface during FTS. We also measured the cobalt weight concentrations in 30CoC-N2 and 30CoC-R-H2 by TGA and found that they were rather similar (28.8 and 28.6 %). Thus, no noticeable carbon loss confirms that the mild conditions for the catalyst activation and regeneration were optimally chosen. 4 Conclusions The structure evolution of the Co/CNT catalysts with Co loadings of 20 and 30 wt.% during preparation, activation, long-term FTS tests at relevant conditions, regeneration, and re-tests was studied. Comprehensive physicochemical characterization of both catalysts and supports by TEM, XPS, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, and TGA-MS allowed tracing the structure transformations in the catalysts. The activities and TOFs of the catalyst did not depend on the metal loading because of the high capacity of the oxidized CNT surface towards the active phase. Particle sintering, wax accumulation and carbide formation were observed after 3-week test. Considering the time of stream dependencies of conversion, particle size and phase composition of the catalysts we suggested the wax accumulation to be the main reason for catalyst deactivation, which agrees with the recently published data for oxide-supported cobalt FTS catalysts. Viscous heavy hydrocarbons block pores and active sites hindering the diffusion of reagents, intermediates, and products, which significantly decreases CO conversion. Though the noticeable sintering of cobalt particles was observed, it could play a positive role in the case of CNT supported catalysts in which even at high cobalt loading of 30 wt.% the excellent dispersion of metal particles was observed. At the same time, the smallest particles of less than 5 nm in size showed poor activity. Sintering of these particles during the induction period of FTS increased both the C5+ selectivity and activity of the catalysts. Even after 500 h of the test, the catalyst contained predominantly 5–15 nm particles that are the most active in FTS. The metal loading in the catalysts significantly affected the growth of the cobalt particle size because, on the one hand, higher cobalt loading decreased the distance between particles, but on the other hand, it increased the FTS rate and, hence, led to a higher partial pressure of water. The study of the support evolution during all stages of catalyst lifecycle showed that CNTs significantly lost surface oxygen during catalyst annealing, but more gradual defunctionalization was observed during the subsequent stages. Compared to the previously published data the soft and optimally chosen activation and regeneration conditions in the present study slowed down this process as much as possible. Nevertheless, the surface oxygen plays the main role during nitrate impregnation and does not significantly affect the catalyst stability at the subsequent stages. The Raman spectroscopy data confirmed that the structural changes were not introduced into the CNT support under the mild activation conditions. Only the reductive regeneration increased the defectiveness of CNTs due to the presence of wax during this treatment. Based on the result of our work we can propose the following regeneration procedure. A simple hydrogenation of the used catalyst is enough to restore its activity to the maximum value but a preliminary reactor purge with inert gas at ∼250–350 °C is necessary to preserve the support structure. Air exposure is only required when the activity loss is irreversible. This treatment re-disperses cobalt over the support surface. Varying the oxidation temperature, the degree of this effect can be tuned. At 300 °C all wax is removed from the catalyst, while CNT structure is not affected. In summary, this work shows that Co/CNT system is highly stable and suitable for FTS at industrial conditions. The optimal choice of the preparation, activation, and regeneration conditions allows maximizing benefits from the CNT support (high metal dispersion, absence of complex oxide formation, and excellent heat dissipation). We believe that this work will bring CNTs closer to large-scale applications in FTS and other catalytic processes. coredata.dc:description: Though carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are widely applied in industry, their large-scale use in catalysis is still limited. This work studies cobalt-based CNT-supported catalysts with 20 and 30 % metal loadings in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis at relevant conditions. The evolution of catalyst and support structures was analyzed by a combination of physicochemical methods at different stages of catalysts preparation, long-term tests, regeneration, and re-test. Wax accumulation was suggested to be the main reason for catalyst deactivation, while sintering and carbidization did not strongly affected the catalyst performance. Moreover, sintering played a positive role by increasing conversion and C5+ selectivity because of the consolidation of low active small particles. The reductive regeneration of the used catalysts restored their maximum activities. The mild and optimally chosen conditions of the catalyst preparation, activation and regeneration preserved the support structure improving the overall stability of the Co/CNT catalysts that is necessary for large-scale catalytic applications.
coredata.dc:title: Structural evolution, stability, deactivation and regeneration of Fischer-Tropsch cobalt-based catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes
